nYInOdl9s4SRvxRZSNmCog.text: Having neglected to visit the Breakfast club for many months, i ended up here last weekend when a friend insisted that he liked this place more than Ottolenghi. After having breakfast there, i disagree.Sure the Breakfast Club is popular. We had to queue for more than half an hour to get in at around midday on a Saturday. The interior is not as tiny as the exterior led me to believe. They have a glass roof, which keeps the restaurant lit and warm at the same time ... a big positive in the middle of winter.The menu consists of standard English, American and Mexican breakfast dishes. I ordered the American pancake which, the menu said,  came with almost everything ... sausages, eggs, steak and bacon. I visualised an English breakfast on top of a pancake. It was almost like that (though the steak was absent). It was made well but i thought that the quantity of food was less than what one would expect from an almost £10 price tag. My friend asked for huevos rancheros, which he liked. I tried some chorizos from his plate, which were delightful.The lack of variety among cocktails disappointed me. They primarily served (at least for breakfast) bloody marys and mojitos ... and i don't really like either. So i stuck with a banana milkshake, which was ok. My friend really liked his hot chocolate.The Breakfast Club is a good place to eat, and i shall probably return again. But it does not live up to the hype.

KPHIVvjcb3jsm5Kf0S0RBg.text: The Breakfast Club's Angel branch follows the line of the current tongue-in-cheek 80s revival. They offer breakfast and lunch and dinner options as well, which seems a bit less known as the place is packed with weekend brunchers but not too busy on weekdays. It has a bay window with some seats in it, which are perfect, sunny and overlook Camden passage. Free Wifi and plugs for computer make it a prime location to work a bit outside your own four walls. Good choice of music as well! As a regular, I have to admit though that the staff is not able to deliver a constant high quality service on every day of the week. Some days have a friendly, cool and attentive staff that makes you feel like a king. However, on other days the shift is forgetful and slow and seems to be selected more for their coolness than for their friendliness. (We had to tell one shift to empty the trash can of the juicer so that the fruit flies stop buzzing around our heads...) The same unequal performance is true for the dishes and portion control. So why give four stars for all these obvious faults? When at its best the Breakfast Club is one of the coolest hang-outs in London. Come in on the afternoon and treat yourself to a late breakfast or just a plain coffee, enjoy the unique blend between cafe and bar. Don't bother on the weekend, you are bound to be disappointed queuing for ages to get a slow service from an understaffed place. Instead, come in at the evening and chill out in the bay window.

7X8otSLTpVEs5okS37ZHCA.text: The smattering of reviews for the Breakfast Club are decidedly mixed... but I must admit that I am a fan. Having moved over from New York, I get an inescapable craving for brunch pancakes every few weeks - and this place serves some of the best that I've found in London. Omelettes and Breakfast Burritos? Also very tasty... served with a good amount of spice, tasty cheese, and very addictive home fries (hash browns). Yes, the service can be trying at times (I recently ate here for dinner, and flagging the waitress for the bill was something of an adventure); but on the whole, I do and will continue to keep coming back.

HSO4obMdDeII2o2qbgEGsQ.text: The Breakfast Club in Angel offers a fabulous menu, great smoothies, good coffee and a great relaxed vibe. Whether you prefer a healthy, low-calorie muesli, a full English breakfast, breakfast burrito or eggs Benedict in the morning, you'll find it here. There is something for everybody on the menu. If you want to try something unusual try poached eggs on toast. It is served with yummy homemade tomato chutney and comes with a fresh salad. I do believe however that the bread and pastry selection could be a bit more varied. In terms of service it is true that you'll never know what you'll get. Sometimes the staff is very attentive and quick and sometimes it takes ages for you cup of coffee to arrive. However, since the atmosphere of the place is so lovely and the food it outstanding I have always overlooked that flaw. I have been there on the weekends and you do have to be prepared for a queue and the vibe is not as relaxed, but if you go for a late breakfast at around 12, you'll have a great time. Only place were I ever went for breakfast alone and felt almost like at home!

0ffeFD2ycf-6Wg-usojCiQ.text: I Have visited the breakfast club on 4 occasions. It is not too far from where I work. The location is excellent situated in the funky Camden Passage just up the road from Angel station. The décor of the Breakfast club is a hodge podge of different chairs and school tables, and the walls are washed with posters of Grease and other 80's movies. It is often very busy in here so a table can be hard to get at peak times. The waiting staff are smiley and welcoming, and try and sort out a table for you as quickly as possible. It is a tight squeeze when busy, so not great for intimate chats! The menu is what you would expect for a restaurant dedicated to the all day breakfasts, bacon and eggs, hash browns, as well as American style buttermilk pancakes to boot. You can also get a good range of Americana food like hamburgers and fries as well. The prices are rather high, I can't remember exact prices, but around 8 or 9 pounds for a breakfast which is what I have had the times I have been there. The quality of food is a bit poor, the cuts of meat and eggs seem low quality, especially considering the amount you pay for. Additionally I seem to have been very unlucky as out of the four times I have visited, I have had poorly cooked food. Eggs and potato have been undercooked; food and plates stone cold and pancakes dry and heavy. I am not a big eater, but found the portions to be a little on the small side as well. Having been to America on holiday a few times, I always have high hopes for that same Big Breakfast experience when I have visited The Breakfast Club, but unfortunately I think that I will have to wait until my next visit over the pond, as this venue is sorely lacking in the Breakfast department.

tkOGPHR3_L0_dkWnYW2ffg.text: Sister outlet to the one in Soho, this used to be my local source of American-style grills and blueberry pancake stacks. The excellent atmosphere is made by a combination of the front window seats that hang over cute, cobbled Camden Passage, the collection of kitsch Americana, film posters, polaroids, board games and colourful wallpaper. The food is good too - consistently satisfying if sometimes unspectacular.Unfortunately I say 'used to be' because I've found that the service can be consistently mediocre and sometimes even poor. On more than one occasion I've had an order forgotten by a waiter and once I had to refuse to pay a bill because of the length of time I was left waiting for food. I've also witnessed other customers return meals for similar reasons.Its a real pity, because the prices are reasonable and the food, cocktails and atmosphere are all very pleasant.

lay5MPsSE4jOBuw60kov_w.text: Good solid breakfast with a decent latte. Being from San Francisco brunch is very important and BC did it's job. had the all american breakfast with a side of toast pancakes came with syrup but no butter. Staff very friendly and wait wasnt bad at all though I've always seen a line.

ESiMylIuYDAw7dZuEtST7A.text: Yummmy!! Yes the 11:00am Sunday morning line up can be quite annoying, but it is definately worth the wait! They have an 80's theme with the pictures and the music. The waiters seem quite friendly. It is fairly small place, so everyone is squeezed in tightly. As for the food I was quite impressed with their hollaindase sauce, so you can't go wrong with any of those options. The pancake is more like a crepe but tastes good with maple syrup. I was thrown off and not too impressed with the falafel offered in Veggie all American meal. But overall good way to start of Sunday morning!

Spj3wZO7cjPfk40qmOtW8w.text: There are few more satisfying things than a ruddy good breakfast. Except perhaps a ruddy great cafe with a sense of humour, good food and quirky decor. The Breakfast Club is one such place, a melange of pop culture references, decadent meals and, my favourite, breakfast cocktails.Portion sizes are huge - I'm talking one portion of Eggs Benedict between two here - the staff are friendly if at times a bit forgetful, and the Camden Passage location is genius, The Breakfast Club providing a refreshing change from the wealth of local establishments reverent to an entirely different epoch altogether.

k4uLh4dd8TaZMQB3g1GXmQ.text: I love the Breakfast Club: I know its a bit expensive, and you could call it contrived but I definitely wouldn't. It's cheerful, friendly and a great place to meet with friends or simply sit alone and read or write the afternoon away. I live south of the river and sometimes make the journey north simply on the merits of this little cafe. It makes me happy: it's a bit like a backpacker hostel/cafe that's got it just right, encapsulating an aura of positivity and open-mindedness with a good dose of humour too.Yes the jokes on the menu may seem silly to the London-weary eye, but why not make them? If you're in a good mood they're funny, and the Breakfast Club seems to have the aim of making its customers smile.I love the big sturdy wooden tables, the communal benches, the cheery yellow paint, and the lighting that seems has a great day-light/artifical mix. Despite it's breeziness, it is also cosy and a great place to nurse a hot drink on a winters day.I have spent hours at a time here - it's a good haven away from London's sometimes overwhelming pace. the staff have never made me feel as though I'm over-staying my welcome and have always been friendly and polite.And although the food is a little on the expensive side, it's good and filling, and the breakfast items are especially good.I first discovered the sister branch in Soho, which i also love, but it is this one that takes the crown. I usually come here for an afternoon but have had some good evening meals and breakfasts with friends too. In the summer it's also good to sit outside. Weekends can get really busy so I'd recommend a weekday if you can.

inGo8-WKLZ1GvPNrDxnEdQ.text: The service is still spotty, and the pancakes are still not to my high bar although I loved the vanilla cream, but I am loving this place more and more.  Great wraps, really well-poached eggs, good juices, good salads on the side, kitchy fun decor, and always a random tune playing (inlcuding the inspiration for my 70s Yacht Rock and 80s inspired playlists after hearing a Survivor song off of Vital Signs--sorry I digress).  Worth waiting on the queue!

sNU5rIddosC7684PP3nbfg.text: This little place on Camden Passage near Angel tube station is, as its name suggests, particularly good for breakfasts. I have been there twice and had to wait for a table on both occasions, but the food is good and reasonably priced for the area (could always be cheaper though). Because its small size, you always have to queue on weekends, so make sure you arrive as early as you can make it. My particular favourite is the Vegetarian All American, as it comes with savoury items as well as really yummy pancakes and maple sirup - a two course meal in one! The smoothies are good too, but if you are feeling less health-conscious or generous, the coffees are good too. I would definitely go there again, even if I wouldn't want to spend the cash every week.

photos.caption: Photo of The Breakfast Club - London, United Kingdom

WG4Qh4Cs0SS0klYtAA5T8Q.text: Unsurprisingly I want here for late breakfast as a place to relax and chat with a very health conscious friend. The ambience was relaxed and american; wooden tales, cushionss, stipped pine floor but the ervice was incredibly slow, we waited an eterinity for our order to be taken and slightly indifferent. I ordered an americano, fruit salad and a bacon sandwich. The coffee was good, but split into saucer (I know a bit fernicky, but I like a clean saucer!) and fruit was fresh and an interesting mix. The bacon sandwich was poor: It was just a hunk of bread with some averagely cooked bacon - I ate half. My friend order granola & yoghurt and an OJ (I told you he was a health nut). Both were ok. And it seemed quite expensive. I wouldn't go again. I had high expectations after walking in and it didn't meet them.

L5OOspMSn26iXPPFh38kww.text: Very disappointed with this place, especially after reading the promising reviews and seeing how busy it was.  The wait was long, the food not special AT ALL, the service unremarkable, and overall, just not worth it at all.  I really wanted to like this place, but I definitely won't waste my time or money going back.

omD4yLXbRzgKF_9ceepI5Q.text: The service and food was awful. Waited ages for food to arrive and when it did, it was wrong. No apologies from the staff, just a grunt! Won't be going back.  Try Macondo for breakfast, its much nicer and you can sit outside

qfnqvPx98M_ftkB6ytJbBw.text: I LOVE this place amazing food great breakfast and close to my work can't get enough and the breakfast club one of my fave films :)

r2HrU9OcGNLI834BGMOZpg.text: The first time I daw this cute little place I was immediately attracted by what the board outside said 'We were sitting out, near your parents porch when we met' ...It immediately evoked this aura of the past in my mind, and considering its name-from an 1980's high school flick- it made sense all the pop culture paraphernalia I saw when I walked inside.  The cafe is decked out with stripped wooden floors and simple tables and prices are cheap and food is surprisingly good.  Like the other reviewers there is much to say about the service, but at the end of the day I really didn't mind as I was snapping away to the rhythm of pop culture classics that they play.  I like that they really work hard in providing the whole nostalgia vive, with the decor, the food, even the slow service, it helps to remind you there is no rush (where is the fire?).  It is slow food.  Enjoy the company, enjoy the pancakes, enjoy a healthy smoothie, enjoy life.

9oR0y0wNsqK9TIvhASQQdQ.text: i am a regular at the breakfast club and it is one of my favourite places in london!the general feel of the bc is amazing with its mish-mash of furniture and cosy atmosphere.it is the place to come for brunch! (or lunch infact).the only problem are the queues. especially between around 11 and 1 you'll defo have a wait of about 20 - 30 mins max but if you go early then you won't have any problems.i recommend the amazing chorizo hashbrowns, eggs benedict and the pancakes. blue monday to drink.oh and don't forget to pick up a badge!!

y4apkrhW-CAHopEwe75AcA.text: A colour and cheer-ful place to have a nice but over-priced breakfast or lunch, but you get the feeling it's all a bit contrived - maybe suffering from the Camden Passage syndrome of trying too hard to be quirky / kitsch - but I guess it is quite interesting and worth a visit once at least. The service isn't so good, but the coffee and biscuits are - and the smoothies are pretty impressive. It's a good place to go with a hangover, which will maybe help you justify paying a bit more for fairly average food, but don't make a special trip there unless you're still wasted and find a tenner in your sock.
